repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - First, Second, Third, and
            Fourth Economic Rehabilitation and Recovery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The four projects examined for Sierra
            Leone, the First, Second, Third, and Fourth Economic
            Rehabilitation and Recovery (ERR) Project. Ratings for the
            First, Second, Third Economic Rehabilitation and Recovery
            Credit Project were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Ratings for the
            Fourth Economic Rehabilitation and Recovery Credit Grant
            Project were as follows:  outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            and the Bank and the Borrower performance were satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included:  overall, the ERR operations
            were effective in providing critical budget support to
            Government of Sierra Leone (GOSL) during the initial
            post-conflict years. The effectiveness was greater in
            directly supporting the demobilization effort under the DDR
            program, achieving the initial protective, social, and
            economic security advances, and in accomplishing process
            improvements, than in achieving better governance, improved
            allocation of budget resources and development results in
            the longer run. Early start of Bank interventions and
            informed risk taking can help consolidate the peace process.
            Delayed adoption of a country strategy and programmatic
            budget support weakens ownership, creates funding
            uncertainty, and hampers capacity building under the
            circumstances. Stronger signaling of longer-term resource
            availability for budget support and capacity-building
            substitutes for the lack of formal programmatic framework.
            While project or program designs were kept simple and
            realistic, more could have been done to develop an
            appropriate results framework calibrated to post-conflict
            country circumstances. The Bank is (often) expected to
            assume a leading role in mobilizing and coordinating
            external donor assistance in post-conflict situations, and
            is not always adequately resourced to do this. In
            recognition of this, post-conflict Bank programs may benefit
            from senior management support that would enable country
            teams to more appropriately structure and adequately
            resource their efforts in mobilizing and coordinating donor assistance.

repnme.cdata!:
Kick starting Sierra Leone's
            post-conflict economy

abstracts.cdata!:
Protracted civil war destroyed Sierra
            Leone's physical and social infrastructure. The peace
            agreement of July 1999 provided an opportunity for the World
            Bank to prepare a program of support for economic
            rehabilitation and recovery. A series of three credits
            provided quick-disbursing post-conflict support to finance
            governance reform and stimulate economic growth, to
            implement a transitional safety net allowance for adult
            ex-combatants, to finance public services, and to import
            essential commodities - including food products, petroleum
            products, and raw materials and intermediate goods needed to
            kick-start the economy. With the establishment of a full
            poverty reduction strategy paper covering 2005-2007, there
            is now consensus among the major donors that the best way to
            make progress in Sierra Leone is through a framework for
            multi-donor budget support and a clear and consistent set of
            conditions that flow from the poverty reduction strategy.
            This framework was put into place in November 2006 and
            underpins a new series of development policy grants for
            governance reform and growth.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Economic Rehabilitation and
            Recovery Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory. Project sustainability is regarded aAs likely
            although this assessment must be qualified by three factors:
            1) the difficulty of maintaining fiscal discipline in light
            of the extensive social and economic needs of the country,
            especially as new areas open up to Government control; 2)
            upcoming presidential and parliamentary elections pose the
            possibility of additional expenditure demands and/or the
            emergence of elected authorities less committed to a reform
            agenda; and 3) finally, and most importantly, the potential
            for security setbacks, either from a slowdown or reversal of
            the disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration program
            or from cross-border destabilization, remains real. Overall
            World Bank performance is rated satisfactory and Borrower
            performance is assessed as highly satisfactory. The key
            lesson learned is that short-term, post-conflict operations,
            while not without risk, can address near-term recovery
            needs, as well as lay the foundation for growth and
            structural reform in the mid-term, when a) an over-arching
            and well-conceived interim strategy is in place; b) donor
            assistance is undertaken in a comprehensive and integrated
            fashion within the context of that strategy; c) there is
            close complementarity between the government's economic
            recovery program and demobilization and reintegration
            efforts; and d) the authorities are firmly committed to the
            program's objectives and policies.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Economic Rehabilitation and
            Recovery Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Rehabilitation and Recovery
            Credit will help finance the 2000-01 year slice of the
            National Rehabilitation and Recovery Program in Sierra
            Leone, focused on sustaining peace, and restoring security.
            The operation will be a quick disbursing credit, providing
            the critical balance of payments, and budgetary support to
            partly finance the foreign exchange, and budgetary costs of
            establishing all three dimensions of security, i.e.,
            protective, socioeconomic, and, transparent governance. The
            proceeds will allow the import of essential commodities -
            food, petroleum, and, raw materials - required for
            re-launching the economy. Local currency funds will enable
            the provision of basic services, restoration of law and
            order, and the necessary infrastructure, required in a post
            conflict situation, in addition to contributing to
            transitional safety nets for ex-combatants re-entering civil
            life. The Credit will complement the support provided by the
            European Union, the International Monetary Fund, and the
            British Department for International Development, and will
            be implemented parallel to the Community Reintegration and
            Rehabilitation Project. Regardless of possible risks, -
            deterioration of the political situation, governmental unity
            failure, and implementation delays due to capacity
            weaknesses - the economic recovery, envisaged to curb
            inflation, while maintaining a macroeconomic stability, far
            outweighs the risks.
